name: classical mechanics
description_1: Branch of physics that deals with the motion of macroscopic objects under the influence of forces| following principles established by Isaac Newton.
description_2: A field of physics focused on the movement of large objects and the forces acting on them| based on ideas first formulated by a famous scientist from the 17th century.

name: dynamics
description_1: A branch of mechanics that deals with forces and their relation primarily to the motion but sometimes also to the equilibrium of bodies.
description_2: A study that explores how forces affect objects| particularly their movement| but also their balance in some situations.

name: statics
description_1: Branch of classical mechanics that is concerned with the analysis of force and torque acting on a physical system that does not experience an acceleration| but rather is in equilibrium with its environment.
description_2: A section of physics that looks at systems where forces are applied| but the system remains balanced and doesn't accelerate.

name: acceleration
description_1: The rate of change of the velocity of an object with respect to time.
description_2: The measure of how quickly an object's speed changes over time.

name: impulse
description_1: Change in momentum of an object.
description_2: The variation in an object's momentum due to external influences.

name: displacement
description_1: Change is position of an object.
description_2: The shift in an object's location from one point to another.

name: force
description_1: Influence that can cause an object to change its velocity unless counterbalanced by other forces.
description_2: A push or pull that can alter an object's speed or direction unless other factors counter it.

name: frame of reference
description_1: Abstract coordinate system whose origin| orientation| and scale are specified by a set of reference pointsâ€“geometric points whose position is identified both mathematically and physically.
description_2: A push or pull that can alter an object's speed or direction unless other factors counter it.

name: inertia
description_1: Tendency of object in motion to stay in motion and objects at rest to stay at rest.
description_2: The natural tendency of objects to maintain their current state| either moving or at rest| unless acted upon by an external force.

name: weight
description_1: Force acting on an object due to acceleration of gravity.
description_2: The pull experienced by an object due to the gravitational acceleration of a planet or celestial body.

name: mass
description_1: Intrinsic property of a body. Believed to be related to the quantity of matter in a body| until the discovery of the atom and particle physics. It was found that different atoms and different elementary particles| theoretically with the same amount of matter| have different masses.
description_2: A fundamental characteristic of an object| once thought to be tied to the amount of matter present| but later found to differ even among particles with seemingly similar amounts of matter.

name: momentum
description_1: Product of the mass and velocity of an object.
description_2: A measure obtained by multiplying an object's mass by its speed.

name: space
description_1: Three-dimensional continuum containing positions and directions.
description_2: A boundless| three-dimensional field that includes all possible positions and directions.

name: speed
description_1: The magnitude of the change of its position over time.
description_2: The rate at which an object's location shifts over a given period.

name: time
description_1: Continued sequence of existence and events that occurs in an apparently irreversible succession from the past| through the present| and into the future. It is component quantity of various measurements used to sequence events| to compare the duration of events or the intervals between them| and to quantify rates of change of quantities in material reality or in the conscious experience. Time is often referred to as a fourth dimension| along three spatial dimensions.
description_2: The ongoing progression of events and existence from the past to the present| and into the future| often considered an irreversible process. This dimension is crucial in sequencing events| comparing durations| and measuring rates of change in both the physical world and conscious experiences.

name: torque
description_1: Rotational analogue of linear force. It is also referred to as the moment of force| or abbreviated to moment. Just as a linear force is a push or pull applied to a body| a torque can be thought of as twist applied to an object with respect to a chosen point.
description_2: A twisting or turning force applied to an object| similar to a linear push or pull| but focused on rotation around a specific point.

name: velocity
description_1: The speed in combination with the direction of motion of an object.
description_2: The combined measurement of how fast something is moving and in what direction.

name: newton
description_1: The unit of force in the international system of units (SI). One newton is| the force needed to accelerate one kilogram of mass at the rate of one metre per second squared in the direction of the applied force.
description_2: A standard unit for measuring force| defined as the amount of force required to move a kilogram of mass by one meter per second squared.

name: first law of motion
description_1: A body remains at rest| or in motion at a constant speed in a straight line| except insofar as it is acted upon by a force.
description_2: An object will stay still or continue moving in a straight line at the same speed unless influenced by an external force.

name: second law of motion
description_1: At any instant of time| the net force on a body is equal to the body's acceleration multiplied by its mass or| equivalently| the rate at which the body's momentum is changing with time.
description_2: At any given moment| the total force on an object is equal to the object's mass multiplied by its acceleration| or the rate at which its momentum changes over time.

name: third law of motion
description_1: If two bodies exert forces on each other| these forces have the same magnitude but opposite direction.
description_2: When two objects apply forces on each other| these forces are equal in strength but act in opposite directions.

name: body
description_1: Collection of matter with a defined contiguous border in three-dimensional space.
description_2: A group of matter that occupies a specific| continuous region within three-dimensional space.

name: distance
description_1: Mesurement of how far apart the objects are.
description_2: A measurement indicating how much space separates two objects.

name: newtons law of gravitation
description_1: Every particle attracts every other particle in the universe with a force that is proportional to the product of their masses| and inversly proportional to the square of the distance between their centers.
description_2: Every object in the universe pulls on every other object| with the force being stronger if the objects have more mass and weaker as the distance between them increases.

name: free fall
description_1: Any motion of a body where gravity is the only force acting upon it.
description_2: A type of movement where an object is only influenced by gravitational pull.

name: gravity
description_1: Fundamental interaction observed as mutual attraction between all things that have mass.
description_2: A fundamental force that causes any two objects with mass to attract each other.

name: vacuum
description_1: Space devoid of matter.
description_2: An area completely empty of any physical matter.

name: projectile
description_1: Object propelled by the application of an external force and then moves freely under influence of gravity and air resitance.

name: centripetal force
description_1: Force that makes a body follow a curved path. The direction of this force is orthogonal to the motion of the body and towards the fixed point of the instantenious center of curvature of the path.

name: keplers first law
description_1: The orbit of a planet is an ellipse with the Sun at one of the two foci.

name: keplers second law
description_1: A line segment joining a planet and the Sun sweeps out equal areas during equa intervals of time.

name: keplers third law
description_1: The square of a planets orbit period is proportional to the cube of the length of the semi-major axis of its orbit.

name: orbit
description_1: Curved trajectory of an object such as the trajectory of a planet around a star| or a natural satellite aroun a planet etc. Normally| refers to a regularly repeating trajectory| although it may also refer to a non-repeating trajectory.

name: orbital period
description_1: Amount of time a given astronomical object takes to complete one orbit around another object.

name: ellipse
description_1: Curve surrounding two focal points| such that for all points on the curve| the sum of the two distances to the foci is contant.

name: foci
description_1: A point that helps define an ellipse| parabola or hyperbola.

name: semi-majo| semi-minor axes
description_1: Longest and shortest diameter of an ellipse.

name: potential energy
description_1: Energy held by an object due to its position relative to other objects| stresses within itself| elastic charge or other factors.

name: kinetic energy
description_1: Energy held by an object due to its motion.

name: law of conservation of energy
description_1: Total energy in an isolated system remains constant.
